sentences.sentence: On the very night after Jefferson Hope’s arrest, the aneurysm burst, and he was found in the morning on the floor of the cell.
Holmes and I were now at home resting when we heard the news.
We were speaking about the case and everything that had happened.
“I confess( 坦白 ),” said I, “I still don’t know how you solved this case.”
“I hardly expected that you would.
Let me see if I can make it clearer and show you the different steps in my reasoning.
To begin at the beginning. I approached the house, as you know, on foot, and with my mind entirely free from all impressions.
I naturally began by examining the road, and there, as I have already explained to you, I saw clearly the marks of a cab.
I confirmed by inquiry( 询问 ) that the marks must have been there during the night.
I was certain that it was a cab from a cab company and not a private cab, by the narrow tracks of the wheels.”
This was the first point gained.
I then walked slowly down the garden path, which happened to be a clay soil, peculiarly suitable for taking impressions.
To my trained eyes, every mark upon its surface had a meaning.
There is no branch of detective science which is so important and so much neglected( 被忽略的 ) as the art of tracing( 追踪 ) footsteps.
I saw the heavy footsteps of the officers, but also I saw the track of the two men who had first passed through the garden.
It was easy to tell that they had been before the others, because in places their footprints had been entirely covered by the others coming after them.
In this way, my second link was formed, which told me that the visitors were two in number.
One visitor was remarkable for his height (as I deduced( 推理出 ) from the length of his steps), and the other was well-dressed, as was shown by the small and elegant impression left by his boots.
On entering the house, this last assumption was confirmed.
My well-booted man lay before me. Then the tall one had done the murder.
There was no wound upon the dead man’s body, but the expression upon his face assured( 使确信 ) me that he had learned of his fate( 命运 ) before it came upon him.
Men who die from heart disease, or any sudden natural cause, would not show fear upon their faces.
Having smelled the dead man’s lips, I sensed a slightly sour smell, and I came to the conclusion that he had had poison forced upon him.
Again, I deduced( 推理 ) that it had been forced upon him from the hatred and fear expressed upon his face.
And now came the great question as to the reason why.
Robbery had not been the object of the murder, for nothing was taken.
Was it politics, then, or was it a woman?
That was the question which confronted( 面临 ) me.
Political murderers would leave as soon as possible.
On the contrary, this murder had been done most deliberately, and the murderer had left his tracks all over the room, which showed that he had been there for a long time.
It must have been a private reason, and not a political one.
When the word was discovered upon the wall, I was even surer of my opinion.
When the ring was found, it settled the question.
Clearly the murderer had used it to remind his victim of some dead or absent woman.

I then proceeded to make a careful examination of the room, which confirmed me in my opinion as to the murderer’s height, and gave me the additional details( 细节 ) as to the Trichinopoly cigar and the length of his nails.
Since there were no signs of a struggle, I had already come to the conclusion that the blood which covered the floor had burst from the murderer’s nose in his excitement.
It is seldom that any man, unless he is very full-blooded, breaks out in this way through emotion( 情绪 ), so I assumed that the criminal was probably a strong man with a reddish face.
Events proved that I had judged correctly.
Having left the house, I proceeded to do what Gregson had neglected( 忽略 ).
I contacted the head of the police at Cleveland, limiting my questions to the circumstances connected with the marriage of Enoch Drebber.
The answer told me that Drebber had already applied for protection against an old enemy in love, named Jefferson Hope, and that this same Hope was at present in Europe.
I knew now that I held the clue( 线索 ) to the mystery( 谜案 ) in my hand, and all that remained was to catch the murderer.
I had already determined in my own mind that the man who had walked into the house with Drebber was none other than the man who had driven the cab.
The marks in the road showed me that the horse had wandered on in a way which would have been impossible if there was anyone in charge of it.
Then where could the driver be? He must be inside the house.
Lastly, if one man wished to follow another through London, what better means could he adopt than to become a cab driver?
All these considerations led me to the conclusion that Jefferson Hope was to be found among the cab drivers of the London.
If he had been one, there was no reason to believe that he had stopped.
On the contrary, from his point of view, any sudden change would be likely to draw attention( 注意 ) to himself.
He would continue to do his job for a time at least.
There was no reason to suppose that he was going under an assumed name.
Why should he change his name in a country where no one knew his original one?
I therefore organized my Street Arab detective corp( 小分队 ), and sent them to every cab company in London.
How well they succeeded, and how quickly I took advantage of it, you know.
The murder of Stangerson was an incident which was entirely unexpected, but which could hardly have been prevented.
Through it, I came into possession of the pills.
You see the whole thing is a chain of logical( 逻辑的 ) sequences( 序列 ) without a break or a flaw( 差错 ).”
“It is wonderful!” I cried. “Your merits( 功绩 ) should be publicly recognized.”
“See here!” he continued, handing a paper over to me, “look at this!”
I read, “...It is an open secret that the credit of this smart arrest belongs entirely to the well-known Scotland Yard officials, Mr. Lestrade and Mr. Gregson.
The man was arrested in the rooms of a man named Mr. Sherlock Holmes.
Mr. Sherlock Holmes himself showed some talent in the detective line.
With such teachers as Lestrade and Gregson, Mr. Holmes may learn some their skill...”
“Didn’t I tell you so?” cried Sherlock Holmes with a laugh.
“That’s the result of all our Study in Scarlet( 猩红色 ): to get them more praise!”
“Never mind,” I answered, “I have all the facts in my journal, and the public shall know them.
In the meantime( 同时 ), you will have to be content with your own knowledge of your success.”

article_info.previous: Jefferson为了误导警察，在墙上写下“Rache”。同时他也交待了如何杀害Stangerson。真相终于大白，这一切都正如Holmes所料。
article_info.share_words: You see the whole thing is a chain of logical sequences without a break or a flaw.

question.cn: 在Jefferson被捕后发生了什么？
question.en: What happened to Jefferson after his arrest?

options.en: He died due to the burst of aneurysm.

analysis: 在今天故事的开头写道，“On the very night after Jefferson Hope’s arrest, the aneurysm burst, and he was found in the morning on the floor of the cell.”说明Jefferson因为动脉瘤破裂而死，故选B项。

question.cn: Holmes怎样得知Drebber是被迫服下的毒药？
question.en: How did Holmes get to know that Drebber was forced to take poison?

options.cn: 从他惊恐的表情和嘴唇的酸味。
options.en: From the terrible look on his face and the sour smell of his lips.
From his twisted arms and legs.

analysis: 文中当Holmes检查被害人尸体时说道“... but the expression upon his face assured me that he had learned of his fate before it came upon him. Having smelled the dead man’s lips, I sensed a slightly sour smell, and I came to the conclusion that he had had poison forced upon him. ”说明是通过他惊恐的表情和嘴唇的酸味得知被害人是被迫服毒，故选A项。

question.cn: Holmes为何会认为这不是一次政治谋杀？
question.en: How did Holmes assume that it was not a political murder?

options.cn: 因为政治谋杀案的凶手通常都会尽快离开。
options.en: Because political murderers would leave as soon as possible.

options.cn: 因为这次案件的凶手写了错误的德语。
options.en: Because the murderer wrote the wrong German word.

options.cn: 因为这次案件的凶手在罪案现场留下一枚戒指。
options.en: Because the murderer left a ring at the crime scene.

analysis: 文中当福尔摩斯在描述自己的推理过程时说道“Political murderers would leave as soon as possible. On the contrary, this murder had been done most deliberately, and the murderer had left his tracks all over the room, which showed that he had been there for a long time. ”说明政治谋杀案的凶手都会尽快离开，而这次案件凶手并不是这样，所以排除政治谋杀的可能，故选A项。

question.cn: Holmes是怎样得知凶手的姓名的？
question.en: How did Holmes know the murderer’s name ?

options.en: Asked the head of the police at Cleveland.

analysis: 由文中片段“I contacted the head of the police at Cleveland...The answer told me that Drebber had already applied for protection against an old enemy in love, named Jefferson Hope.”说明是通过询问Cleveland的警察局长得知了凶手的姓名，故选A项。

question.cn: 根据报纸的描述，破获这起凶案是谁的功劳？
question.en: According to the newspaper, who got the credit for solving this case?

analysis: 文中当Holmes看到的报纸写到“It is an open secret that the credit of this smart arrest belongs entirely to the well-known Scotland Yard officials, Mr. Lestrade and Mr. Gregson.”说明报上写的这起案件的成功是Gregson侦探和Lestrade侦探的功劳，故选C项。

question.cn: Dr. Watson是如何认识Sherlock Holmes？
question.en: How did Dr.Watson come to know about Sherlock Holmes?

options.cn: 他的老朋友介绍了Sherlock Holmes。
options.en: His old friend introduced Sherlock Holmes.

options.cn: 他在报纸上读到过Sherlock Holmes的消息。
options.en: He read about Sherlock Holmes on the newspaper.
Sherlock Holmes was an old friend of his.

analysis: 文中提到Dr. Watson偶遇老朋友Stanford并表示自己找住处，Stanford随后说“You are the second man today that has used that expression to me”从而开始介绍Holmes，故选A项。

question.cn: 为什么Dr. Watson见到Holmes时很惊讶？
question.en: What surprised Dr. Watson when he met Holmes?

options.cn: Holmes知道他从何处回来的能力。
options.en: Holmes’s ability to tell where he came from.

analysis: Holmes第一次与Dr. Watson见面时，说出了Dr. Watson从阿富汗回国，“‘How on earth did you know that?’ I asked in shock.”此处表明Dr. Watson对Holmes这个观察力表示十分惊讶，故选B项。

question.cn: Holmes如何处理对自己没用的知识？
question.en: How did Holmes process the knowledge which was not useful to him?

options.en: He tried to write it down.

analysis: 文中提到“Now that I do know it, I will do my best to forget it.”可以知道Holmes处理对自己没用的知识时，通常会忘掉，故选A项。

question.cn: 谁写的《生活之书》这篇文章？
question.en: Who wrote the article The Book of Life?

analysis: 文中提到夏洛克说“As for the article, I wrote it myself.”说明这篇文章是夏洛克自己写的，故选B项。

question.cn: 带给Holmes的信是什么内容？
question.en: What was the content of the letter which was brought to Holmes?

options.en: A crime needed to be solved.
A greeting letter from his friend.

analysis: 文中提到信的第一句写到“There has been a bad business during the night at 3, Lauriston Gardens, off the Brixton Road. ”结合后文分析得知是一场凶杀案发生，需要Holmes的帮忙，故选A项。

question.cn: 在房间角落里发现了什么？
question.en: What was found in one corner of the room?

analysis: 文中提到“Across this bare space there was blood-red letters.”说明角落墙上写着血红色的字，故选A项。

question.cn: Holmes认为血字意味着什么？
question.en: What did Holmes think the meaning of the blood letters was?

options.en: It was a German word for “revenge”.

options.cn: 意味着受害者是德国人。
options.en: It meant that the victim was a German.

analysis: 文中提到Holmes表示“ ‘Rache’ is the German for ‘revenge’, so don’t lose your time looking for Miss Rachel.” 说明“Rache”是德语“复仇”的意思，故选B项。

question.cn: 根据Holmes的说法，为什么凶手会重回到罪案现场？
question.en: According to Holmes, why would the murderer come back to the crime scene?

options.cn: 为了拿走受害者的钱包。
options.en: To take away the victim’s wallet.

analysis: 文中提到在Watson询问Holmes凶手为何会返回现场，Holmes肯定地回答“The ring, man, the ring. That was what he came back for.” 说明他认为凶手是为了戒指回来的，故选C项。

question.cn: Lestrade侦探在哪里发现的Stangerson先生的尸体？
question.en: Where did detective Lestrade find the body of Mr. Stangerson?

analysis: 文中提到“‘I have just come from his room,’ said Lestrade.” “I was the first to discover what had happened.”由此可知，答案选C。

question.cn: 从这个故事中，我们可以得知关于药片的哪些信息？
question.en: What did we learn about the pills from this story?

options.cn: 一片药有毒，另一片无毒。
options.en: One of them was poisonous, another one was harmless.

analysis: 文中描述Holmes在证实自己的猜想后，很激动地说“Of the two pills in that box, one was of the most deadly poison, and the other was entirely harmless. ” 说明药盒中的药，一片是有毒的，一片是无毒的，故选C项。

question.cn: Jefferson Hope杀害Drebber和Stangerson的动机是什么？
question.en: What was Jefferson Hope’s motive for killing Drebber and Stangerson?

analysis: 从书中可知，Drebber和Stangerson害死了Jefferson Hope的爱人及爱人的父亲，因此他一心想要杀死两人，为自己爱的人复仇，故选C项。

question.cn: 为什么Jefferson Hope要留住Lucy的结婚戒指？
question.en: Why did Jefferson Hope keep Lucy’s wedding ring ?

options.cn: 因为戒指是Jefferson仅有的关于Lucy的物品。
options.en: Because the ring was the only thing Jefferson had of Lucy.
Because the ring was extremely beautiful.

analysis: 文中描述Jefferson自述道“I was shocked at this, for it was the only thing that I had of her. ”说明这戒指是Jefferson仅有的关于Lucy的物品，所以他才会一直保留着，故选B项。

question.cn: Dr. Watson与Holmes是怎样的关系？
question.en: What was the relationship between Dr. Watson and Holmes ?

analysis: 从书中了解到，Dr. Watson想找人合租房子，并通过朋友介绍认识了Holmes，从而成为室友，故选B项。

question.cn: 哪一个词能最好描述Lucy的生活？
question.en: Which word can best describe Lucy’s life?

analysis: 文中描述Lucy的父亲被他人杀害，自己也被迫嫁给别人，并且在一个月内就重病身亡，通过这些叙述可以得知她的生活是悲惨的，故选B项。

question.cn: 在故事的最后，Dr. Watson说“我将这些事实都记在日记里”是为了做什么？
question.en: At the end of the story, what did Dr. Watson mean by saying “I have all the facts in my journal”?

options.cn: 他可能会发表关于这个案件的真实故事。
options.en: He might publish the true story about this case.

options.cn: 他可能会告诉房东太太这个故事。
options.en: He might tell their landlady about this story.
He would do nothing about it.

analysis: 通读全文可知，Dr. Watson得知报上将所有功劳都归功于两位侦探后说“I have all the facts in my journal, and the public shall know them.”说明他会让公众知道真实的故事，故选A项。

question.cn: 下面哪一项关于Sherlock Holmes的陈述是正确的？
question.en: Which of the following statements is true about Sherlock Holmes?

options.en: Sherlock Holmes loved literature and politics .
Sherlock Holmes was a police officer.

analysis: 文中描述Holmes的公寓有很多访客，请Holmes帮忙，且这些访客来自各个阶层，故选C项。

question.cn: Jefferson在杀害Drebber和Stangerson后有什么样的计划？
question.en: What was Jefferson’s plan after killing Drebber and Stangerson?

options.en: Turn himself in to the police.
Save enough money to get back to America.

analysis: 文中Jefferson承认自己的罪行后说“I went on working with my cab for a day or so, intending to keep at it until I could save enough to take me back to America. ”且Holmes也推测他会继续工作，故选B项。

question.cn: Jefferson为自己杀害两人感到后悔吗？
question.en: Did Jefferson have any regret for killing two men?

options.en: Yes, he regretted for killing them.

options.cn: 不，他觉得自己做了一件正确的事。
options.en: No, he thought that he had done the right thing.

analysis: 文中描述Jefferson一直被仇恨支配，一心只想杀人报仇。在被审问时也表示自己做了一件正确的事情，说明他对自己的罪行并不后悔，故选B项。

question.cn: 下列哪项关于Dr. Watson的描述是正确的？
question.en: Which of the following statement is true about Dr. Watson?

options.en: He was shot by a bullet once.

options.cn: 他足够有钱负担一间昂贵的公寓。
options.en: He was rich enough to afford an expensive apartment.

analysis: 文中描述Dr. Watson在战场上被子弹击中后，健康状况急转直下，且因为囊中羞涩需要找人合租，故选A项。

question.cn: 根据这个故事，Sherlock Holmes最重要的才能是什么？
question.en: According to the story, what is the most important talent of Sherlock Holmes?

analysis: 根据书中的情况可得知，Holmes破案最主要就是靠细心观察推理，所以他最重要的才能应当是善于观察的才能，故选C项。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第20天
